Package fr.ens.biologie.generic.utils

Class Statistics

java.lang.Object
fr.ens.biologie.generic.utils.Statistics
public class Statistics extends Object
Functions to compute statistics iteratively. They all return stat(n+1) as a function of x, n, and stats(n). Optimised for speed.

This class performs statistics using values that regularly come in. It assumes the values come from a single variable which values evolve over time. It would be badly wrong to use only one instance of this class to track both an integer and a double variable, since all values would be mixed in a single distribution. The use pattern is as follows: 

 stats = new Statistics();
 stats.add(x);
 stats.add(y);
 stats.add(z)
 stats.average(); // returns the mean of x, y and z
 stats.n();       // returns 3 (number of observations)
 stats.reset();   // prepares for a new series of numbers

CAUTION: successive additions of observations (calls to an add(...) method) must keep the data type consistent, i.e. it would be nonsense to add observations that represent different kinds of variables, objects, etc. All observations are supposed to come from a single source. The meaning and consistency of the computations cannot be checked in this class and is left to the user.

Author:
Jacques Gignoux - 21 juin 2017

    • doubleFrequencies

      public SortedMap<Double,​Integer> doubleFrequencies()
      The frequency distribution of all floating point values received since last call to reset(). CAUTION: to make sure integer constant values representing a floating point number are treated as floating points, do not forget to multiply them by 1.0, otherwise they will be counted as integers.
      Returns:
      a map of counts per floating point value
